div1.p: FALSTAFF'S WEDDING, A COMEDY: AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
BEING A SEQUEL TO THE SECOND PART OF THE PLAY OF KING HENRY THE FOURTH.
WRITTEN IN IMITATION OF SHAKESPEARE, BY W. KENRICK.
LONDON, Printed for L. DAVIS and C. REYMERS, in Holborn; and J. Payne, in Pater-noster-Row. MDCCLXVI.

div1.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div1.p: THE success, which a juvenile sketch of this Play hath met with in publication, having induced the Author to bring it on the stage; he flatters himself the alterations, which were thought necessary to accommodate it to a theatrical audience, will not give less satisfaction to the reader than such scenes as he was obliged on that account to reject.

div1.head: PROLOGUE.
div1.byline: Spoken by Mr. DODD, in the Character of MERCURY.
div1.stage: [Mercury descends from the clouds, flying across the stage: Re-enters, followed by a servant, carrying a counsellor's gown and wig.

lg.l: A LA MERCURE, equipp'd from top to toe,
My godship's name and quality you know.
Commission'd from Apollo, I come down
T'attend this bench of justices, the town.
Assembled here; all members of the quorum:
To lay a matter of complaint before 'em.
The errand's not in character, 'tis true;
But what our betters bid us, we must do.
Therefore, t'appear with decency at session,
I've stole, you see, the garb of the profession.
This gown and band belong to serjeant Prig—
And this—our brother Puzzle's learned wig.—
Dress makes the man, Sirs, vestis virum facit—
So—now to business—Hem!—si vestris placet—
May't please your worships—Forgery, which is grown
To such a height as ne'er before was known—
I say, a forgery hath been committed,
By which king Pluto's mirmidons, outwitted,
Certain choice spirits, in theatric shape,
Have suffer'd from Elisium to escape;
Of Shakespeare's offspring and ideal train,
Sprung, Pallas like, from an immortal brain!
Their names—I have 'em down—but, to be brief,
Shall only just enumerate the chief.
Imprimis, with Madeira swell'd, and sack,
There's Sir John Falstaff, alias call'd Plump Jack;
Next, captain Pistol, a notorious bully;
And Miss Dol Tearsheet, fam'd for jilting cully;
The widow Quickly, vintner, bawd and whore.
With Bardolph, Peto, Nym and—several more;
Link'd in a gang, each cut-purse with his crony,
All arrant thieves and Dramatis Personae;
Bent, as suppos'd, to prostitute to shame
Th' aforesaid Shakespeare's honour, name and fame.
I shall not trespass on your worship's time,
T' explain at full the nature of this crime:
But, Poets having an exclusive right
To bring their mental progeny to light,
This right's invaded by the party 'peach'd;
Who, vi et armis, hath th' old bard o'er-reach'd.
By counterfeiting of his hand, do ye see,
Feloniously to set these vagrants free;
With base design t'adopt them for his own,
Tho' Shakespeare's property, and his alone.
Such is the fact.—A critic were an ass,
No doubt, to let such imposition pass;
Nor could a cheat so palpable succeed,
But that the captain of the guard cou'dn't read—
No, not for laughing, tho' to've sav'd his soul;
The scene and circumstances were so d roll.
Pistol, with yellow night-cap patch'd with red,
With Mother Quickly was retir'd to bed;
And, waking, swore, by Styx, he would not come,
Sans preparation, pike and beat of drum.
Of aqua-vitae having stole a flaggon,
Bardolph and Nym were playing at snap-dragon;
Sometimes proceeding from hard words to blows,
As by mistake Nym seiz'd on Bardolph's nose.
With Falstaff sat Dol Tearsheet, cheek by joll,
And while she buss'd his chin and scratch'd his poll,
Slipp'd from his thumb his grandfire's copper ring,
For love, not for the value, of the thing:
Then stole his empty purse; but no abuse;
'T was only done to keep her hand in use:
He swearing, he'd be damn'd as soon as trust his
Round belly more with Hall, or his chief-justice.
But this is wandering from the point.—They're here,
And on your summons ready to appear:
Please to proceed then to examination;
And be attentive to their information.
If, as your judgment cannot be erroneous,
You take this forgery to be felonious,
The author meaning fraud, I need not mention
Your issuing warrants for his apprehension;
And when you've caught and into pieces tore him,
Hang up his mangled carcase in terrorem;
In flagrant crimes the process should be short;
The law is clear—I leave it with the court.

div3.head: SCENE I. A Street in WESTMINSTER, On the Day of the Coronation of King HENRY the Fifth.

sp.p: WHAT a scurvy quarter is this? Not a bush, or a blind Cupid, in the neighbourhood! 'sblood, my legs will fail me ere I reach a tavern. Phoo—Phoo—It is some comfort, however, I escap'd with my life. The green-apron'd rascals, crouding after the procession, had well nigh made an end of me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: O, Sir John, I'm glad I have found ye. I was in the fearfullest quandary for you in the world. I hope your honour has got no hurt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not its death's wound, I hope; though Hal, indeed, look'd somewhat cold upon me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Cold, Sir John! I am a-fear'd we shall be in limbo shortly: for my Lord-chief-justice—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hold thy ill-omen'd croaking. If faithful services are thus requited, I will turn cordwainer; yea, cobler, and heel piece old shoes, ere I have to do with blood-royal again. Ingratitude! I hate it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: To be sure, Sir John, what you say is right; for, as the song says, ingratitude is worse than the sin of witchcraft. But I hop'd your honour got no personable harm in the mob: you was carried off the terras, for all the world, like a danghil from Mill-bank by a spring-tide.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolph, away with thy filthy comparisons! I am ill at ease, and more dispos'd to spleen than to merriment. I prythee, look out, and see if there be a bawdy-house at hand.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What here, so near the court, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Where better? 'Sblood, dost think there are no whores at Court? Are there no dames of honour? Dost think Hal hath banish'd them too? Look out, look out.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I will, Sir John.

I would I were in East-cheap. Mine hostess hath a most excellent cordial; and I never stood in more need of it than now. The gross indignity Hal hath put on me, sticks in my throat; and, in the end, may go near to choak me. I shall never gulp it down: that's flat: unless, indeed, a full cup of sherris help to clear the way. And then, how I shall stomach it; how I shall digest it, heaven knows! At present, both my person and knighthood are in jeopardy; my Lord-chief-justice, to whose care I am commended, holding me not altogether in good liking. But no matter—if I am to be provided for, what avails it who is my caterer? I could wish, nevertheless, old white wine stood higher in his Lordship's favour; that I may not be stinted at table, or in my by-drinkings. I like notsuch splenetic temperaments; such phlegmatic constitutions; grey-beards, that never make allowances for the continual waste of radical moisture.—'Sblood,
I am as foundered and as sore as a blind horse in a mill.—Bardolph! where a plague art thou gotten to, caterwauling?

div3.head: SCENE IV.
div3.stage: Enter Mrs. QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O, Sir John Falstaff!

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: O, sweet Sir John!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How! mine hostess, and my good vestal Mrs. Tearsheet! save ye gentlewomen both, good-morrow.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Godild ye, Sir John—well I vow and protest an I didn't say he would take as civil notice of his old acquaintance: nay, tho'f he was created by my lord-mayor of London.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: What talk ye of lord-mayors and fusty citizens, gossip Quickly? Sir John is a courtier, and to be sure we must gratulate him now as one of the greatest knights in the nation.—O sweet Sir John!—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Truce with your formalities, Mrs. Dorothy. Pray, have you seen none of our followers by the way? Pistol, nor Peto!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No verily, Sir John, not one.—We have seen nothing of any of them to day. They are all gone to the coronation, I warrant; and indeed we should have been there too, hadn't it been for that wicked villain, constable Fang, that, by a mistake of the beadle of our ward, would have carried us to Bridewel this morning.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How! mine hostess and my fair Dorothy to Bidewel!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Even to Bridewel, I can assure ye.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But how; how? dame Quickly to Bridewel! a decent church-going widow and a modest maiden, I should say, single gentlewoman, to a house of correction! why, what—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
So I said, Sir John. Nuthook, Nuthook, says I, do you know what you do, says I?—Have me to Bridewell, says I,—I say to Bridewel indeed! a ruptable house
keeper, that has paid scot and lot, and born the burthen of half the parish any time these twenty years.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: That thou hast, hostess; of the male half, I'll be sworn for thee.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Besides, says I, do you know Sir John Falstaff! says I.—Touch a hair of Mrs. Dorothy's head, says I, and Sir John will make you smart for it, says I, ev'ry bone in your skin, says I.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And what said the rascal to that?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Said, Sir John! he stood mumchance, and spoke never a living syllable, but set his vinegar-visag'd catchpoles upon us; who fastened their claws into Mrs. Tearsheet's best kirtle, and tore it into as many rents and tatters, as there were in the old tapestry hangings I pawn'd to fit your honour out for the last expedition.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir John, made a mere tatterdemallion of me. But we did so tongue the leather-ear'd vultures—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: That they were glad to loose their gripe to get rid of you, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, I was obliged to perduce an angel to convince them we were not the parties indicted.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Infidel rogues! would nothing less than the testimony of an angel convince them?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ay, I knew how Sir John would take it. O, how soundly will the knave constable be swing'd for this! a jack-in-office rascal! we shall cure the blue-skin'd runnion of his itch for whipping, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: I have been looking all about, Sir John, but I cannot find one.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What is it Sir John wants, Mr. Bardolph?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A bawdy-house, mistress.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O Jesu-Maria! Mrs. Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
How, sirrah! what call'st thou a bawdy-house
I sent thee to look out for a house of civil entertainment, where I might repose myself after my fatigue? Why, what, you rogue, would you make of me?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Marry come up indeed! a bawdy-house truly! but as to a house of civil entertainment, Sir John; here is one hard by, where the knights and lords, and all the great gentlemen of the court, are entertained, both by night and by day, as civilly as at their own homes; and by gentlewomen as kind to them, I warrant ye, as their own ladies themselves.—A house of civil entertainment, a bawdy-house! Why, I keep a house of civility myself, and I would have you to know Mr. Bardolph—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'tis all one: what Sir John pleases.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, by my truly, and so I think it ought, for if Sir John recommends you to the king—

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay, were I Sir John, I'm sure I would never promote such a clown as Bardolph at court.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ah! Dol, Dol, I am afraid our promotion will be at the gallows. If Sir John has any interest with the hangman, he may get me preferr'd, perhaps, to the top of the ladder.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why, how now varlet?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Do you hear? do you hear, sweet Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, hostess, Bardolph is somewhat blunt: but, as for the king—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Heav'ns bless him! a sweet young prince he was; and, to be sure, a gracious king he is. But what of him, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, marry,—hang him, hostess—Treason must out as well as murder.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I am 'maz'd Sir John; why, how is this? what a goodness! when—where—

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: How is this, good Bardolph?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, I will tell ye how it is. That same ungrateful, speaking, pitiful rascal, we are speaking of, is turn'd fanatick.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Fanatick! the king a fanatick!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, fanatick, presbyter, bishop, if you will. Let his crown be his mitre; I care not.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: We don't take your meaning, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You must know then, Dol, that after having, in pure love and affection, ridden post day and night fourscore and odd miles, to congratulate him on his accession, and condole with him on his father's death; instead of bidding me welcome to court, he preached me my own funeral sermon.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A funeral sermon!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, hostess: for at the end of his discourse he order'd me to be buried alive, at ten miles distance from the court. And, to make this unnatural interment the surer, he has appointed my Lord-chief-justice his undertaker, to see to the disposal of my corpse.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Buried alive, quoth he! what, what is in all this?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: In plain terms, dame Quickly, your gracious king hath banished me the presence; and, till he grows a graceless prince again, I am forbidden to approach his person, within ten miles, on penalty of being hang'd, Take ye me now?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O Jesu! is it possitable?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ah, ha! is it so? sits the wind in that quarter?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well, as I am an honest woman, who would have thought it? it is a world to see!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And so, Sir John is in disgrace; still plain Jack Falstaff and one of us! ha! ha! ha! poor blown Jack!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A sad disappointment, indeed, Sir John! but, in good faith, things fall out so odd, and the world goes so wrong, and the times are so hard; that here, there, why, no longer ago now than yesterday, was I obliged to pay the lord-knows-what-all away for one thing or other: and then my misfortune to day; an angel to the constables; and besides this comes the day after to morrow, when I must make up a sum for the wine-merchant: wherefore if your honour would but discharge your score in East-cheap; because, as why, your honour knows—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How's this, dame Quickly?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Because, I say, as why, your honour knows, seventy odd pound is a great deal of money for a poor widow woman to lose.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What talk you of losing, hostess?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: True, Sir John, as you say, to be sure, I shall not be willing to lose it: for the law is open, and I know which way to get my money.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am glad thou dost, hostess: as in that case I need not give myself the trouble to pay thee. The law is open, say'st thou? Ay, like a mouse-trap, on the catch for nibbling clients. Enter thy action, and I will hold thee a gallon of sack, thy departed husband will get out of purgatory ere thou out of the hands of thy lawyer.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, you need not twit me upon that. You need not fling my poor husband's soul in my teeth. He has not been gone so long; tho' for the matter of that he might have been in heav'n before now, hadn't I lent you the money Mr. Dumb should have had to say masses for him. Yes, Sir John, you have put into that great belly of yours what should have got my poor husband out of purgatory, and now you reproach me for it. Had he been still alive you would not have us'd his disconsolate widow thus. You wouldn't, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No, I'll be sworn I should not.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well then, Sir John, out of charity, if it were nothing else, you ought to repay the money. Nay, if you don't, I'll pray night and day that you may be haunted by his ghost. Heav'n rest his soul. I would he might never sleep quietly in his grave, till he has made you pay me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to, thou art a foolish woman: with good words thou may'st be paid.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, Sir John, good words will not do. I must have money Sir John. The priests won't get a soul out of purgatory without money. Besides, Sir John, good words are no payment, I can get no body to take them: good words will not do with me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, well, I say you may be paid—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: May! Sir John, I must.—You have thus shuffled off and on me, a good while; but I must, I must be paid, I must—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Heigh! heigh! wilt thou raise the neighbourhood on us? If thou art clamorous, I will have thee duck'd
in the Thames, for a bawd. What, a-plague, art thou drunk? On the honour of my knighthood thou shalt be paid. Dost thou doubt mine honour?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, Sir John, to be sure, no-body would scruple to conside in your honour's honour: but then you know Sir John (no-body better) what honour is. It will buy neither coals nor candles; nor will my landlord take it for rent, nor the merchant for sack or sherry. But would you give me only the half in money, and leave the rest to honour; so that a body might keep open house, Sir John. That would be doing something.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, if thou wilt be advis'd, I will do more for thee.—Bardolph! forget not to go (when I send thee) to the cashier, with whom I left a thousand pound this morning, and tell him to satisfy Mrs. Quickly forthwith.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A thousand pound!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: The times are not so bad, hostess (thanks to our friend Shallow) but we may yet have a merry bout in East cheap.—How says my Dol!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay, you know, sweet Jack, I was always at your pleasure there.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: That I will say for her, and a sweeter-natur'd better hearted creature never lay by the side of a true man Bat, goodness heart! why do we tarry here, when Sir John complain'd of his being fatigued, and was looking for a house of civil entertainment? I will shew you the way incontinently, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I thank thee, hostess; I am now somewhat recruited, and will endeavour to reach Eastcheap. And ye a cap of sack, by the way, I think, would not be amiss

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Hang Pistol up with line of hempen string, Ere he in rabbet-hutch be close immured.—Seize the stiff cramp upon the fangs of justice.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Marry-trap, we shew'd his myrmidons a light pair of heels tho'. I wonderwhat is become of Sir John. They have certainly nailed his fat paunch. We must not venture to the Fleet to see. They'll nab us there: and for the matter of that, I suppose they'll be running the humour upon us here too. I will incontinently go and shut myself up. The storm may blow over when we are found uninventible.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Pistol disdains to skulk. Nolens, 'tis fate: But who would volens be incarcerate?

sp.speaker: Nym,
sp.p: we must eat, and money have we none.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: True, nolus volus, as you say, we must eat. I like to starve, like a rat, behind the arras, as, little as another man. But what shall we do if Sir John be in limbo?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.l: Or in or out; his follower I no more.
Invention's mother is necessity,
And Pistol's demon is an imp of wit.
Merc'ry suggests, and Pallas doth approve.
The great Ponjardo del Stilletto's dead,
Professor of the art of self-defence.
His broken foils, his daggers, belts and blades;
The stock in trade, I'll purchase upon tick:
My face, disguis'd with an usurped beard,
These jutting eye-brows, turn'd from black to red,
Shall skreen from knowledge. Thou shalt too assume
A borrowed excrement, and partner be
In stock and block: since fighting's grown a trade,
Pence are pick'd up by masters of the blade.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: The thought is lucky. Angels will ensue. But must we not transmutify our names?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: My brain's my godfather, and, at the font, Me, Don Anticho del Pistolo, called.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: And pray what did this same godfather call me?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Signior Nymwego!

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Good! Signior Nymwego! and you Don Anticho del Pistolo! I will hold them in oblivion. The trick of it pleases. But, here comes Quickly and Dol.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So, Gentlemen! you are got home before Sir John, I see.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: How fares the knight? Is he in durance vile?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, by my truly; he returns forthwith; but in a woful plight. Francis! What, Francis! Bring the great chair for Sir John.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.p: Anon, Anon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: to Nym. Sirrah, Nym, hath Falstaff got money by him?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Yes, a thousand Pound; he borrowed it of Justice Shallow: but we shall be little the better for that; for the knight will certainly be in limbo.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: May be, no; and may be, yes. It is no matter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Does the humour hold? Or shall we wait the coming of the knight?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: And share his fate in base incarceration! Shall Don Anticho del Pistolo prove A vile hunt-counter? No—We'll thrive alone. Hostess farewel; we may return—or not.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Bye Dol.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis certainly so; Sir John hath got the money.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I know not that; but if he has, he'll probably carry it to jail with him. Here comes Bardolph, ask him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Is Sir John at hand, Bardolph?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: He will be here incontinently, hostess: I only stept before, to let you know he was a coming.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: But is it veritably true, Bardolph, that Sir John has got a thousand pound by him?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ay, is that true, Bardolph?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: True, upon honour; he had it of justice Shallow, of Gloucestershire; and it lies now in master Gingle cash, the banker's hands. But Sir John will be here momentably. Is ev'ry thing ready?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: In a minute we are all clear. Run, good Dol, and receive the knight at the door. Francis! what, Francis!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: (without) Anon, anon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Light up candles in the passage. A bottle of sherris, Francis, quick, you sleeping knave.—Always upon a snail's gallop! O that ever woman should be plagu'd with such creeping varlets!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O, here is Sir John, himself.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Jaded to death, I warrant!—An easy chair, good Bardolph. Please you to depose yourself, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Soh! now have I taken up my sitting again, in my old quarters. A glass of sherris, Francis!

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: And how do you find yourself, my sweet knight?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Tolerably thirsty. (Drinks) I can drink; and that is all the bodily functions I am capable of. I am as sliff,
ev'ry part about me, as a walking taylor, or Don Diego on a sign-post.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, if that be the case, it is not over with you yet. Give me a buss.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go, Dol, you are riggish—get you gone you water wag tail, you; I am not merrily dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: But, will you give me a new kirtle at Bartlemew fair?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will, Dol.—Nay, I cannot bear you on my leman.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why, how came you so terribly maul'd, my leman?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Did not I tell ye?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir John, your honour spoke of fatigue; but did not descend to particles.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well then. I will tell ye now. Give me first a glass of sherris. (Drinks) You must know that, after the king (hang him for a sheep-stealing cur) gave me that rebuff I told you of; he stalk'd majestically away, and left me to the mercy of the multitude: when, as I stood parleying with mine antient; mine arms a kembo thus; a knot of elbowing carls bore me down before them, with the impetuosity of a torrent. Lo! there was I, jamm'd fast in the midst of a vile groupe of mechanics, as if we had grown together in a body corporate: and in this jeopardy was I carried along; sometimes bolster'd up on all sides, at the confluence of several turnings, like a May-pole; and at others, wire-drawn between two stone walls, as if they meant to make chitterlings of me: now this fair round beliy taking the form of a Christmas pye, and by and by press'd as slat as a pancake. It is a miracle I did not burst in the midst of them. Had it nor been for the sufficiency of my buff doublet, I should have certainly bursted.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: If you had, Sir John, you would have went off with a report like a bladder.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A bladder, ye jade, a demi-culverin at least. I should have died an hero: my exit would have made some noise in the world.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid, Sir John, you should ever die a virulent death, I say.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I hope, indeed, sweet knight, you will never be press'd to death. That must be an odd end, and yet methinks I could bear much.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I'll be sworn thou could'st, Dol: but thou art a woman, and made to bear.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, in good sooth, poor woman is made to bear ev'ry thing. She must suffer all a man's ill humours; let 'em lie never so heavy upon her: and, by my truly, some men are nothing else. But, to be sure, Sir John, you was most unhumanly used. Would no body take pity upon you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pity! the most remorseless rascals! they made no more of me than if I had been a lump of dough, they were kneading to make dumplings of: and to expostulate with the villains, would have been preaching to the winds.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why did not you exert your courage, Sir John? draw upon them?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Draw, sayst thou? I could not come at my rapier, to be master of a kingdom. And as for good words, in return for the few I gave them, they let fly their jests so thick at me, and pepper'd me so plaguly with small wit, that I was dumbfounded.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I thought you could never have been overmatch'd that way, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Yet so it was, Doll. They were holiday-wits, and came loaden with choke-pears: bur, indeed, I was overcower'd by numbers. Two to one, Doll, you know—They pelted me from all quarters. Will you hear? I wiil give you a spice of their farcasms; a sample of the gibing pellets they threw at me. As I was thus stemming the tide, and crying out for the lord's sake, a dried eel's-skin of a fishmonger ask'd me how I could complain of the croud. Is a porpoise ill at ease, said he, amidst a glut of sprats and herrings? I had not time to answer the smelt, before a barber-surgeon, the very model of the skeleton
in his glass-case, offered to tap me for the dropsy; and to make us all elbow-room by letting out a puncheon of canary, at my girdle. Right, cries a third, at the word canary, I'll be hang'd if any thing be in the doublet of that fat rogue but a hog's-skin of Spanish wine; and incontinently they roar'd out, on all sides, Tap him, there,—tap him, master surgeon.—'Sblood; I was forc'd to draw in my horns, and be silent; lest the villains, being thirsty, should force the shaver to operation. The knave, indeed, was five weavers off, and so could not well come at me; I might otherwise have been drunk up alive.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And pray how cam'st thou off at last, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: By mere providence: for, after the barbarous rascals had squeez'd the breath out of my body, they buffetted me because I could not roar out, God save the king. At length, I know not how, they threw me down in the cloisters, where, falling cross-wise and the way being narrow, I fairly block'd up the passage: upon which (for they could not straddle over me) they took, another way (a plague go with them!) for fear of losing the show. And thus was I left to take in wind, and gather myself up at leisure.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And did the mangy villains so play upon thy sack but? a parcel of sapless twigs! dry elms, fit only for fuel! I would I had the burning of them.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Wouldst thou fire them, Dol? Ha! art thou touch wood still, Dol?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, not so.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, I'll be sworn, Sir John, to my carnal knowledge, if there be truth or faith in medicine. But Sir John, what would your honour please to have supper?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Another glass of sherris—fill me out, Bardol I cannot eat. I have lost my appetite by the way. Put egg into a quart of mull'd sack, and give it me when a-bed. I will to sleep.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Would you have your bed prepar'd, strait, John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, on the instant, good Dol. Hostess! go thou and see to the brewage of my sack.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Sir Knight, I bring thee news: loud same reports My lord-chief-justice hath recall'd his warrants.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I would he were choaked with his warrants, ere he had issued them. But I thank thee for the tidings. The serjeants will not disturb my rest, at least to-nighr. But, what comes here?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: From ducking-pond escaped in dripping plight,
The crooked-finger'd cut-purse, Peto hight.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What's the matter, Peto?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Matter! Sir Knight and master of mine! Matter faith enough. The mob at Westminster had like to have murder'd poor Peto here.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And how so?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Why, Sir John, as he was getting upon a cobler's pulk, to see what was become of your honour, araw-bon'd waggering serjeant, coming by, whipt hold of him by the leg, and threw him on the people's heads; where they shoulder'd him about from post to pillar, as they would have done a hedge-hog, or a dead rabbit that had been shrown among them. I saith, I thought they would have kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
How! was that Peto? I saw the bustle at a distance,
and wonder'd what the porters and 'prentices had got, to make sport withal. By the Lord, Peto, I have a fellow-feeling for thy sufferings.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: And I. But say, is merit thus repaid? Shall fortune play the jilt with men of mould? Go, Peto, lay thy head in Parco's lap.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good Peto, let me advise thee to go to bed, And lay thy head on a pillow. Bardolph, see to him. Pistol and Nym, good night.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: and Nym. Good night, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Francis!
sp.l: Light me to bed—let Dol bring up the sack,
See to the urinals, and tuck up my back.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Signior Nymwego! Hear'st thou lad of craft?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Yea, marry, Don Anticho del Pistolo—runs the humour well?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Well, Nym. and thou and I, o'er cup and can,
Will go, and schemes of operation plan.

div3.head: SCENE I. A Street.
div3.stage: Enter Justice SHALLOW and Master SLENDER.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I Wonder now, Coz; when you know what a desperate kind of a horrible man Sir John is, you shou'd—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut, tut.—I fear him not; there's ne'er a Sir John Falstaff in the nation shall over reach me.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: But what's done can't be help'd, Coz; he overreach'd you now, as I take it, when you lent him the money.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Well, cousin of mine; then it is my turn now to over-reach him, and get it again.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: That, indeed, cousin Shallow, to be sure would be quite right; tit for tat, as we say in the country; but then he is such a bloody-minded caitiff; you know he broke my head once for nothing at all: and if he should get an inkling that you are going to law with him, O Lord, O Lord, I shall never sleep in quiet again.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Poh, you chit, if he breaks the peace, I shall know what to do with him, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, there indeed, cousin, ecod, I did not think of that. If I am in fear of my life, I can answer taking him up with a warrant, and binding him over to his good behaviour. Suppose therefore, Coz, we swear the peace against him first, and lay him fast by the heels before we enter the action.—And yet I don't know, if I might advise ye, I would wash my hands of him.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Talk not to me. I tell thee I will spend half my estate, ere the rascally knight shall carry it off so. I had rather the inns of court should share the money among
them, than that the gorbellied knave should feast his enormous guts at any free-cost of mine.—I will to my council immediately; and if the law will not avail me, my sword shall do me justice.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: You know best, cousin Shallow, to be sure; but—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: But me no buts, I say, but come along;
Your cousin Shallow puts up no such wrong.

div3.head: SCENE II. A Street.
div3.stage: Enter an Officer of the King's Houshold and a FRIAR.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: There, good friar, thou hast it: it would little conduce to raise the king's wisdom in the general estimation of the world, to have it thought in the power of such unworthy men as Falstaff and his fellows, to lead him implicitly into all those extravagances under which the character of his youth suffer'd: and yet so it would go near to be suspected, if his highness should now act towards them with an ill-timed severity. My lord-chief-justice hath therefore retracted his hasty orders for their imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Son, well observed; and I commend his lordship's prudence, in treating their vices as infirmities; and will readily undertake to commune with them on the grievous enormity of their dissolute lives.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: His lordship would have you apply first to Sir John Falstaff, the ring-leader of this vicious troop. If you can dispose him to good, the rest may follow.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I will attend these reprobates, and use the means.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: His lordship requires that you would bring Falstaff over to retire to a monastery, if possible; that, being concealed from the eyes of the world, he may not daily remind it of what is past. Farewel, good father; I will see thee again at the Priory.

I will go; but I fear my mission will prove as fruitless as that of many other Apostles, sent among Infidels. As there is no danger of martyrdom, however, I am content.—Persuade Sir John Falstaff to turn monk! could I work miracles, indeed, and, like St. Thomas, turn an Ethiop white, something might be said for it: bur, as it is, I despair of converting an old deboshee from two such prevailing heresies as the whore and the bottle.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Two found naps, of eight hours a-piece, have something recruited me. Bardolph, my morning's whet. Is it prepar'd?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: 'Tis here Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Here's to our better fortune.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ah, Sir John, I am afeard our fortune hath been at its highest stood. We have seen our best days.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
So the world goes Bardolph. Up and down! But is it not hard now? I that have—but that's nothing. I hate boasting. It is, however, well known what pains I have taken to make a man of that Hal. Nay, you yourself are privy to many the good offices I have done him. Before the younker knew me, he could not drink sack; made conscience of going to church on holidays; and blush'd like a scarlet cloak, at entering a bawdy-house. I instructed him in all the manly exercises. I was content to win his money, to teach him gaming: to get drunk myself to try to make him so. Nay, setting rotten limbs and dignity aside, have I not even pimp'd for the bashful rogue?
Such a prince of Wales! by my troth, I was asham'd of him. Had it not been for me, the milk-sop might have been crown'd before he had lost his maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And that would have been a pity, Sir John, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: It was I first taught him to way-lay the true-man; for I knew him when he durst not cry stand to a turkey-cock; nay, a gander, of the ordinary size of a greengoose, had it met him on a common, would have made him run for it. I went farther yet; and not only embolden'd his actions, but taught him the manly arts of conversation. In the stile military, for instance, or swearing.—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir John, I believe, there you forget yourself; the prince wanted no assistance of you in that; for when he was a little crack, he would swear ye as well as a man six foot high.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Right, Bardolph, you are right. I remember me; swearing indeed he knew: for, tho' but a king's son, he would, as thou say'st, rap out an oath like an emperor. But then for the quintessence of all elocution, the use of the hyperbole, vulgarly call'd lying; there I am a master, yet what a deal of pains it hath cost me to teach Hal to lie▪ and all thrown away upon him. He would never do it roundly. He had no genius that way.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You know, Sir John, the prince never could away with lying. He us'd to say 'twas beneath a gentleman and a soldier.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, well, he will never shine in the recital of his own exploits as Xenophon, Caesar, and I, have done.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, Sir John, to be sure, you have done something.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Something! the services I have done him and his father are out of number. Methinks my behaviour, in the ever memorable action at Shrewsbury, should make him blush at his ingratitude. Who kill'd Hotspur? Did not I give him his death's wound in the thigh? Was it not I who took prisoner that fiery dragon Coleville? and that even alive! And am I thus requited? Is this the
guerdon of my great atchievements? Hang valour, I'll hack my sword no more▪ Thus has it ever been the fate of merit to be rewarded. Alcibiades and Bellisarius for that!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, Sir John, they were tall fellows: they were sadly us'd indeed: I have heard of them. But that was in king John's time, I think.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: They were the Falstaffs of antiquity, Bardolph.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Like enough, Sir John: they were before my time, to be sure; though Pistol told me, t'other day, that general Bellisarius was his god father.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistol is an ignorant braggard; an ass: I have injur'd my dignity by associating with rascals, not worthy to wait at my heels. What tell'st thou me of Pistol?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, I meant no harm. I do think you deserve to be made a lord of indeed.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I expected nothing less, I can assure ye. And then, for my well-known oeconomy, to have had the sole management of the exchequer at least.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And instead of that to be banish'd—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I know not if I heard the word banish. I was forbidden indeed to come near the king's person by ten miles; but I was not at that distance when those injunctions were laid on me. Quere now (it might pose a casuist, let me tell ye) whether I am thereby injoin'd to march right out, ten miles an end; whether the negative, not come, amounts to the positive, go.—I will not understand it so; and, if that be my lord chief-justice's construction, by the Lord, I will put him to the trouble of carrying of me: I will be laid up with the gout ere I budge a foot.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir John, the king did say, banish.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Admit it: unless he means to reside for ever in a place, and be in his own proper person as immoveable as a church, I hold my life on a damn'd precarious tenure. He must give me timely notice of his motions, that I may regulate mine accordingly; otherwise, if he be travelling my way, we may happen to encounter, and I get myself hang'd through inadvertency. I do not think it safe, therefore, to stir out of town, without more explicit orders. Give me another draught.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: The tankard is out, Sir John, Shall I replenish?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No. I'll toward St. Paul's: a gentle perambulation this morning may refresh me.

div3.head: SCENE V. A Street.
div3.stage: Enter Justice SHALLOW, Master SLENDER, and a LAWYER.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Well, master Pleadwell, are you still of that opinion. If so, my money's gone?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Indeed, I am still of that opinion, justice Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: What! how! that my money's gone?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Nay, I know not that. I say, I am of opinion you should have taken a bond, or obligation, at the time of lending it, friend Shallow. A thousand pound on the bare word of a courtier; and that courtier Sir John Falstaff! ne'er an alderman in the city of London would have lent a thousand pence on such security.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Oh, that ever a country 'squire should have less wit than a city alderman!

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: A thousand pound, Mr. Shallow, is—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: A thousand pound. I know it is, master Pleadwell, I know it well. But pray now, is there no method in the law to recover it? He cannot have spent it yet: cannot we compel him to restitution? Arrest him—arrest him, Mr. Pleadwell.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: But, should he deny the debt, how will you prove it? and who knows, on such an emergency, what Sir John Falstaff will not do?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nay, he will lye: that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, Coz, and that most consumedly too.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I can prove his receipt of the money.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: But the conditions, justice Shallow—What have you to shew that he is engag'd to return it? and when?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nothing: I was weak enough to lend it him on his bare word.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Nay, cousin Shallow, not so neither. I'll be sworn he borrow'd it upon his oath. He swore upon the honour of a true knight, to give him a thousand pound again; and besides that, the comings-in of a better thing, in his majesty's court at London.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Ah, Master Slender, these knights have just honour enough to swear by; but, for any thing further, I am apprehensive we shall find him one of those honourable knights, whose word is as good as their oath. But see, if I mistake not, yonder he comes; this encounter may perhaps save us the trouble of attending him at home. Let us speak him fair, and persuade him, if possible, to sign an obligation for the money. If we can do that, we may trounce him. Let me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O would you could, Mr. Pleadwell! what would I give methinks to see him well trounc'd! if it was only for giving me once a bloody coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How! Master Shallow consulting with his lawyer! are ye thereabouts, friend Shallow? would you hamper me with an action? (Aside.) I will pass them by.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, Sir John, a word with you, if you please.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O my good friends Robert Shallow, Esq and Master Slender! how fare ye gentlemen both?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Sir John, Mr. Shallow here has—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ha! what mine old acquaintance Master Wheedlepoint! how is it with your health, Master Wheedlepoint?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Pleadwell is my name, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Right.—I cry you mercy—Roundabout Pleadwell, think. My memory is not so retentive as—

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: No offence, Sir John, that is not the case.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Marry but it is, Mr. Pleadwell; a treacherous memory is my great defect: and a misnomer in law thou knowest—

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Would be matter of consequence, Sir John. But that is not our business at present. Mr. Shallow here hath put a case.—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, Master Shallow should know something of the law too. Was not he at Clement's inn when thou wert first enter'd there? That must be many years ago, Mr. Pleadwell.—Let me see. How many years ago must that be, Master Shallow?—Why you carry your age well, Mr. Pleadwell.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Pretty well, pretty well, Sir John, but that—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay marry, I say, very well, Master Shallow. And pray what is become of young Puzzlecause, and Dick Silvertongue, your fellow-students there? they were call'd to the bar, I suppose. That Dick was a prate-a-pace rogue? and a devil among the bona robas. He and Master Shallow here were two with the wenches. Ha, Master Shallow!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: No matter, Sir John, at present we would confer on other business.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, if ye are on business, I crave your pardon, and leave ye. I am not used to be impertinent,

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: You are not going, Sir John; it is with you our business lies.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Business with me!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Yes, about the thousand pound, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What mean you, Master Shallow?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: That you borrow'd of me, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Yes, Sir John, the thousand pound you borrow'd of my cousin Shallow, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Take me with ye, gentlemen, both; let me understand ye. You presented me, indeed, with a thousand pound to promote your interest at court, Master Shallow and may depend on it, if I can serve you—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Fiddle, faddle, Sir John, I expect my money again: your interest at court is not worth a farthing.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I cannot help that; the more is my misfortune, Mr. Shallow; you see my heart is good.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: If so, Sir John, you will not refuse to give Mr. Shallow something to shew for his money, under your hand.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How dost thou know that, Mr. Pleadwell? I must consult my counsel in this case.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: There is no need, Sir John; I will draw up a little instrument, to which thou wilt set thy hand immediately.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not while I have a head, Master Pleadwell, I like not running hand over head in these matters. By latter Lammas, or St. Falstaff's day, I may perhaps bethink me.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: I know of no saint of thy family in the kalendar, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, well, there may be saints of a worse. Our merit hath not stood in the way of promotion; that's all: and yet there are as many whoremasters there as lawyers, I believe; Bun I cannot tarry now to hold farther question with thee; fatigued as I am, and earnest to reach my lodgings yonder.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: If thou wilt there sign the instrument, Sir John, we will attend you thither.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Wilt thou? it is a notorious bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: No matter, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No matter, sayst thou? Is it then no matter for one of the grave sages of the law to be seen in a public bawdy-house? Lord, Lord, what will this world come to! My conscience, however, is more tender: I should be sorry to give such occasion of scandal.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Please you, Sir John, to be serious. Let us rightly understand each other.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
With all my heart, good Master Pleadwell; then, to be plain with you, I find you do not know me. You talk to me of restitution and conditions; did'st thou ever know Sir John Falstaff make restitution on any conditions?
And dost thou think me so unpractis'd a courtier as to return the perquisites of my calling, because I am turn'd out; or to restore the purchase of my good-will, because I am not likely to get in. What take ye me for a younker? a geck? Go to—you cannot play upon me.—Master Shallow, rest you content: your money is in good hands; and, if I do not spend it like a gentleman, never trust me with a thousand pound again.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Oh! that I ever did trust such a caitiff!

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: But, pray, were these the conditions, Mr. Shallow? Was you to be repaid by a place at court?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: To be sure. Why what do you think. Mr. Pleadwell, cousin Shallow was fool enough to lend a thousand pound for nothing? Why, I, myself, was to be made a great man too; and that into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Cousin Slender, speak in your turn, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Were these terms specified?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not indeed on parchment, signatum & sigillatum, Mr. Pleadwell. A courtier's promise is not, indeed, very good in law. But I can tell ye the posts I should have procur'd for these noble 'squires: and by'r lady, thou wilt say they would have been well occupied. Having a little pique or so at my Lord-chief-justice, and Mr. Shallow, here, thinking himself qualified, I promis'd him my interest for his worship's removal from the quorum to his lordship's place on the bench. Was it not so, Mr. Shallow?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Don't belye me, Sir John, don't cheat me of my money, and laugh at me too. Robert Shallow esquire will not put up with that.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Then for Mr. Slender here, I purpos'd, for his address and elocution, to have got him appointed orator to the house of parliament; or otherwise, in consideration of his figure and magnanimity, to have made him a staff officer, or captain of horse, at the least.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, you did not tell me what; but I expected some notable place, I'll assure ye: for I look upon myself, plain 'squire as I stand here, to be somebody.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Coz, coz, you are an ass, coz.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Why, why, I didn't lend him the money; I.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Justice Shallow, this is a very simple affair. I am sorry it is not in my power to serve you in it. Sir John, if you had either honour or honesty, you would restore the money; but, as you make pretensions to neither, I leave you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, my masters, you hear the counsel learned in the law. Will you to dinner with me? You shall see I am no niggard. If you will lodge with me in Eastcheap, you shall see the thousand pound fairly spent in sack: you shall share with me to the utmost farthing. But for dry restitution, I have not been accustom'd to it of many years. You would not have me a changeling at this time of day, I hope, Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Changeling! no, Sir John, thou art no changeling; but, depend on it, I will not put up this wrong. Robert Shallow, esq will neither eat nor drink with thee. If the law will not help me, I will take other methods. I will have my money; depend on't I will have my money.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we shall find means to get the money; ever fear. [Exit Slender.

Nay, I fear it not—at least before I shall have found means to spend it: and then, get it who may; it concerns not me. We shall see, however, whose business will be
done first. Mine will go merrily forward. Ah! shallow Master Shallow! But who could have thought the snipe would have went to counsel, to get himself laugh'd at? Then to see how demurely Sir Slyboots angled for me, as if I had been a gudgeon! How cunningly the rascally barrador would have hook'd me on his instrument! But I was even with the methodical knave.—My friend Shallow will never bring it to bear an action at law; and if he should, I am on the right side of the hedge. Indeed, were I to go to law for a mint of money, I would chuse to have it all in my possession. There is nothing like it. Possession is the very life's blood of a bad cause: on the strength of which in mine, I will home to dinner.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Is this not better than the service mean Of Cappadocian or Assyrian knight? That last young quarreller, how much gave he?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Two marks for entrance and an angel fee.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.l: 'Tis well, keep 'count; and lend attention mute.
Dame Ursula the knight's neglected flame,
Grown rich, is fond of finery and name;
To her hath Don Pistolo made his suit
By love-epistle.—Nym—What sayst thou to't?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: What, rival Sir John! 'Tis true he does not go there now, or he'd make a bloody business of it. You must know I've courted her neice and chambermaid Bridget ever since the last wind-fall.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: And hast thou sped?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Very scurvily, ancient. The jade runs her humours upon me.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.l: Nym, I a letter for thee will indite,
In the true stile of a Castilian knight.
Woman is taken by mere words and whim;
Nymwego shall command what's held from Nym.
But see new swaggerers coming—keep your state.

div3.head: SCENE X.
div3.stage: Enter Justice SHALLOW and Master SLENDER.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ay, this is my old school: here have I had. my sa! and my ha!—Odso, your servant, gentles, pray is Signior Stiletto to be spoken with?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: The valiant wight translated is to heaven.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Faith and troth, I'm sorry for that; heartily sorry indeed.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Ha! sorry! sayst thou, Paphlagonian vile? Wouldst thou in Tartarus that he should howl? Ha!—Ha!

div3.stage: [Draws and makes a lunge at Shallow, who retires.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not I—Not I.—Pray moderate your passion.—Gad's mercy on me what a furious lunge!—Sir, understand me. Signior Stiletto was my honoured master. I had a friendship for him.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: I then embrace thee with a soldier's arm. Stiletto was the glory of the sword, The Ajax, Hector, Agamemnon, he!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: And, if I may ask without offence, pray Sir, what is the name and quality of your worship?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: I his successor am, and men me call Anticho del Pistolo.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: A name of sound, and smacking loud of valour; it sorts well with your figure and profession.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ecod I think so; his name and looks I'm sure make me tremble. I would I were safely out of the house, la!

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Needst thou my service?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
To say the truth, Sir, tho' I am not of a quarrelsome disposition, I have an affair of the sword upon my hands; and, having long laid by my rapier, I came to take a lesson or two of Signior Stiletto; the better to withstand the force of my adversary. Now, since my old
master is dead, I would be obliged to the skill of his successor.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: What is thy name and quality?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: My name is Shallow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Of Gloucestershire, esq justice of the peace and of the quorum.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: A name of note, and smacking much of folly.
sp.l: It suiteth well thy figure and thy purpose.
Nymwego, hand the foils. There, grasp it well;
Bear thy point thus against thy rival's sword,
And had he twenty lives, he falls. Sa—Sa.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Enough, enough, for once brave Sir, enough. I see. indeed, you're worship is a master. Another time I'll try my skill again.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Enough's a feast. Farewel, till next we meet.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: And will not my young 'Squire here enter into the humour of it. Come, Sir, lay hold.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Cod so, not I. I quarrel with no body but my man. And I can break his head at any time for Sixpence. So, I've no occasion, Sir, I thank ye.—Come, Coz, let's go.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir, there's my thanks (gives money to Nym) you'll see me soon again.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my cousin will come again; but I've no occasion I thank ye.

These two 'Squires are precious subjects to play humours on.—I have it too: they've land and beeves; and marry-trap, I will lay a trap for marrying them. Our hostess Quickly and Dol. Tearsheet, when bedizen'd, may pass on these Gloucestershire oass for London dames of rank. Nay, they resemble the wealthy widow of Watling-street, and buxom Beatrice of Bucklersbury, her forward niece. This were a trick of price: I'll fashion it, by working up these noodles into a conceit of their being beloved by the widow and madam Beatrice. I will about it strait.

div2.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: BARDOLPH! How is it with Peto to day!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, he's in a bad way, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: That all!—when was he otherwise? who ever knew Peto or thee in a good way?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And yet, Sir John, we are your followers, you know.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well said, Bardolph.—I see thy wit is improv'd, I lead you the way, it is true; but you follow me, like spaniels, with damnable circumvolutions. But, whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: It is the doctor, Sir John, that has been up to see Peto.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O, doctor Caius Mithridate, the apothecary! a precious limb of Galen!—At Windsor he was a physician, and starved by prescribing poisons, but now he is turned apothecary, and thrives by administering them.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: So, master Doctor, thou art a man of merit, I see—Thou art sought after.—Pray, how many patients may'st thou have dispatched to day?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Pas beaucoup, Sir John—not great many I pay visit betimes, en bon matin, a monsieur de peto.—But I must go now a I'instant, a la cour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, rest you a moment, Dr. Caius, I would commune with you a little on the score of old acquaintance. Pray, master doctor, how came you to leave Windsor? You were, I thought, in some repute there.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: How Came I to leave Windsor! By gar dat Windsor did leave me.—Repute! Morbleu, I was in de best reputation du monde. In dree year, dare vas no less dan dree honderd patients of quality under my hands.—They did never complain of mal-treatment: and yet I did stay dere till I had no patients left.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Dead men tell no tales, Doctor, 'tis certain.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Eh, bien! my patients did die sure enough; but dere was deir sons, deir daughters, deir cousin germans; dey was alive, and commend my treatment of de defunct et non obstant they never would call me in demselves.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: That's much.—But did all your patients die? Say you? Not one survive to trumpet the fame of their doctor!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Yes, by gar, derevas one Bourgeois fort riche et fort mal: he bring me more disgrace than all dose dat vas dead. I did exert all my skill for two, dree year; and he would not be cured.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Then why did you not let him go after the rest?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar he would not go. II a ètè fort entetè, cet homme la. I ave give him opiates, de narcotiques, stronger by gar dan Lethe itself. But he would not be composed; he would live to disgrace me. So he turn me off; and grew well himself, bientôt, presently, without any medicine in the world.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A base Plebeian tyke!

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar, he vas one base fellow, let me tell you dat. De quality no put such affront upon practitioner renommé, un homme comme mol.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Right, master Caius; it is a damned thing when people will not die secundum artem; but live in spite of the doctor. But to the present concern, how is it with Peto?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Oh! j'espere qu'il seroit beintôr gueri; he is in very fair way, Sir Joha.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolph tells me here, he is in a bad one; fair and good, I have heard often; but fair and bad, seldom. But what are his complaints, master doctor? I know something of physick.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Vy, Sir John, de cutis of de occiput est laceré: there be gros tumours all over de corps, de body, De patient has a delire, a vertigo; and besides, de symptomes febriles, de pouls indicate phlebotomy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Phlebotomy! What bleeding?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: A leetel, Sir John—ve vill take avay but sixteen ounces, for un petit revulsion.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Sixteen ounces! Hast thou a design upon his life? What, a plague, wouldst thou kill him? He doth not weigh four pounds averdupoize, flesh, bones and all; and thou would'st take him away by quarterns, in a slop-bason.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Vat is dat, Sir John? vill you instruct me in de patologie, de therapeutice, de indications et contra-indications? Monsieur Peto, must be bled.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bleed sick apes and hypp'd monkies. If Peto be not hang'd, he shall die a natural death. Thinkest thou I'll have his veins drained to fill a row of porringers in a barber's shop window! use bits of red cloth and be damn'd: ye shall have the blood of no follower of mine. Sixteen ounces! I tell thee, not Galen, Hippocrates, nor Esculapius himself, were they alive, should thus operate upon him. Phlebotomy! I will phlebotomize ye all with my rapier, by the Lord, if you offer to draw a lancet on him.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Eh bien done, Sir John; be not in one passion; ve vill take little less; but, by gar de patient vill die, if he no be bled. And let me tell you, Sir John, you vould do yell to lose little blood. En vcrité vous êtes crop phletorique.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Me! I thank thee. But, in the blood is the life of the creature; and I will not consent to part with mine.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: II seroit mieux aussi: it would be better, Sir John, you mix little more vater in your wine.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: More water! I mix none.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Vorse and vorse! By gar, Sir John, if you no
shange your regime, you shall die. Your fat vill eat you up.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I shall eat up many a fat capon first, master doctor.—But would'st thou persuade me, with thy contra-indications, that water is better than wine?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: I our quelques temperamens et dans certains cas; for some constitutions and in some cases, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: For thine, perhaps, but mine thanks thee for thy water. Wine is good enough for me.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Ah! que vous êtes mal avisé. Eh bien, Sir John, you will no take my advice, I leave you. Bon jour—good day to you, Sir John.
Eh! mon dieu! si gras! si gros, by gar, he cannot live long; he will overlay his own belly and burst, if he be not bled.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good day to you, master doctor apothecary. And yet I know not whether I ought to wish that neither; for a good day to him must be a bad one to some-body. A man of any conscience, or humanity, knows not how to salute fellows of such an occupation: for who would wish the rest of mankind lame and blind, sick and sorry, to find them employment, forsooth?—Poor Peto! I would not lose him, methinks; for, tho' he be a worthless knave, he is an old acquaintance; and I never could find in my heart to part with my old acquaintance merely because they were good for nothing. King Hal is another sort of a man to what I am, to abandon his old friends in his prosperity thus. Poor Peto!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ecod, Sir John, it happen'd lucky for me, I can tell ye, that I came off so well as I did yesterday.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, by'r lady, thou playd'st fair to get off in a whole skin, and leave thy friend and master in extremity.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Nay, 'pon honour, Sir John, I did my utmost
to keep up with you: but 'twas unpossible; and indeed it was very fortunable that I was not myself trod to death by the populous.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou! tell me the moon is a Suffolk cheese, or a Windser pear. Thou! have I not seen thee clear the ring without a staff, at a bear-baiting? Thou might'st make thy way through a legion, nay the millions of a croisade: why, who would come within a fathom of that firebrand, thy nose? It is a flaming two-edged sword. Wouldst thou make me believe the villains would come near thee, to burn their holiday cloaths? Thou wouldst have set them a-blaz'ng like stubble, and have consumed the whole procession of heralds, like men of straw. A plague upon them, it was by their avoiding thee, I suppose, that I had like to have died a martyr to corpulency.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir John, you are always plaguing me about my face; what would you have me do with it?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Do with it! If there were water enough in the Thames, I would have thee quench it. But water, I fear, can do nothing for thee; since I remember, when we rode last from Canterbury, when the rain beating full in our faces, thou cam'st into the Borough with thy nose and cheeks glowing red-hot, although they had been hissing all the way like a tailor's goose. God forgive me—but when thou runn'st behind the hedge, in fear of the officer; I could not help comparing him and thee to Moses and the burning-bush. But thou wilt in time be consumed: thy fire must out.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I would it were out, so be I might hear no more on't. In troth, Sir John, if I must always be your butt, I shall seek another service I assure you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, nay, good Bardolph, that must not be. I speak not in disparagement, heav'n knows: for I mean to cherish thee against the lack of fuel, or the visitation of a Dutch winter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: 'Sblood, Sir John, I'll bear it no longer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hold, Bardolph, where art thou going? thou
glow-worm in magnature with thy tail upwards; thou pumpion-headed rascal, stay, or—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Give me good words then, Sir John. Why pumkin head, pray now?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hast thou never seen a scoop'd pumpion set over a candle's-end, on a gate post, to frighten ale wives from gossiping by owl-light? That is a type of thee—that is thy emblem: thy head being hollow, full of light, and easily broken; as thou shalt experience, if thou offer'st to fly thy colours till disbanded by authority. I shall need thee, I tell thee, to keep me warm under the coldness of the king's displeasure.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir John, burnt sack and ginger will do you more good: for whatsomever light I may give, I am fare, set aside choler, I am as cold as e'er a white-liver'd younker in town.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Cold, sayst thou! thy face would condemn thee for an incendiary before any bench of judicature in the kingdom! thou wouldst carry apparent combustibles into court with thee. Tell not me of cold. Thou wouldst certainly have been hang'd long ago, had not the sheriff been afraid thou wouldst have fir'd the hangman or the gibbet.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, Sir John, I have been your attendant off and on these twenty years, come Candlemas; and I don't find I have had any such effect on you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: The cause, you rogue, the cause; am not I oblig'd to keep a pipe of Canary constantly discharging on me? Are not the tapsters perpetually employed? the sackbuckets for ever a going, to keep me from blazing? And yet at times my skin is shrivell'd up like an April pippin. Mark me but walking an hundred paces, with thee glowing at my heels, if I do not broil and drip like a roasting ox.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ah, you are pleased to be hard upon me, Sir John, but I am sure my face never hurt a hair of your head.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No! look at 'em—hath it not turn'd them all
grey? Twenty years ago, before they were calcin'd by thy fire, my locks were of a nut-brown.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, you grow old, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Old! what call ye old? I am a little more than threescore: and Methusalem liv'd to near a thousand. Why may not I be a patriarch, and beget sons and daughters these hundred years, myself?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Then you must get a wife, Sir John, for your common fields, you know, never bear clover.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Marry! what to be made a cuckold of, I warrant ye?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, Sir John, if you should marry, you would not like to be singular, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Fal,
sp.p: Nay, for the matter of that, all's one: but who will have me? Your dames of breeding are too fine and finicking tor me to bear with them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ay, or for them to bear you either, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, whoever has me, she must be no tenderling; she must be none of your gingerbread lasses, that will crumble to pieces in the towzling. She must be none of your wishy-washy, panada gentry neither; your curd and whey gentlefolks, that cannot support the embraces of a soldier, I must have a kicksy-wicksey of more substantial stuff.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, Sir John, what say you to Madam Ursula, your old sweetheart? You have courted her to my knowledge these twenty years last past. I suppose you know her great aunt is dead, and has left her four hundred marks a year.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No, by the lord, I heard nothing on't. She sent me a letter, indeed, into Gloucestershire; but I was over a bottle, and would not interrupt the glass to read it. I knew it was hers by the superscription, which by the way, however, was as unintelligible as the hand-writing on the wall. It had never reached me had not the bearer been a decypherer. Go, Bardolph, and fetch it; you will find it among other trumpery in my cloak bag.

Four hundred marks a year, quoth he! It were not an unreasonable competence were not sherries comparatively so dear. But if the female incumbrance on it should turn out a shrew; the Lord have mercy on me, in thus paying off the sins of my youth. Let me bethink me. Four hundred marks a year! I have, it is true, small hopes from Hal; and shall grow old some time or other. These aches in my limbs forebode it. I cannot hold out for ever; that's certain. Were it not good, therefore, to make a virtue of necessiry, and take up while I am in case to reap the credit of reformation? Could I reconcile it to my interest, I believe my inclination would follow.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: There, Sir John, is the letter.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Come on: let us see if we are master of so much Arabick as to find out our meaning. (Reads) Hum—hum—hum—! Why, dame Ursula, thou hast a memory. I could have credited thee for subtlety, on account of that old friend to woman, the serpent: but how thou couldst remember for fifteen years together what money I owed thee—that indeed I cannot account for. I have myself forgot it long since. She tells me here, I have borrow'd five hundred pounds of her at times, as tokens of my love. By the Lord, and as I am a soldier, I will love her still, and she shall command semblable proofs of it. (Reads on) Hum—hum—Repayment of the money
or the performance of my engagements! Hoo! am I then to be married on compulsion? That will go most damnably against the grain. But hold—if I marry, her money will be mine: if nor, she may cease to lend when she pleases: and the fortune of that man is always at the turning of the tide, who depends on the caprice of a woman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, marry her, then, Sir John. I dare say she has heard nothing of your disgrace at court; so that she won't stand upon terms.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Marry, Bardolph, and I am half resolved to do so. Yea, by the Lord, and I will too. She has besides two thousand pounds in money, I will courageously make the attack and mount the breach of matrimony. If I sall into the hands of Philistines; why, good night. It is but going into purgatory a few years before my time, Bardolph, get me pen and ink, in the cupid. Thou shalt be one of love's messengers.—I will write to her in trope and figure: metaphor and hyperbole carry all before them with the women. Let her resist lyes and nonsense if she can.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: But do you think, Nym, they won't discover us?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Not if you mind the trick of it, and don't betray yourselves. The old 'squire is as rampant as a goat, and conceited as an ape. And as for the young one, he has but four senses out of the five. Let not your breath smell of aquavitae, nor your lips smack of bawdry. Array yourselves antique, look modest and speak supernaculum. Do this, and they'll never suspect you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O, let me alone for speaking supernaculum; I have a set of the courtliest phrases in my huswisry book! I'll con them by heart.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Well, go, prosper: Pistol will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Fear not—we'll lose no time: come, Dol, we shall be made women, if this plot succeeds.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And do you think, Bridget, Sir John will be at last as good as his word, then? How sits my ruff to-day? I would thou hadst bought me one of those new-fashioned farthingales.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: O, madam, you are mighty fine, as it is, truly: and, I am sure, Sir John can do nothing less than admire you.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Thinkest thou so, Bridget? Why, to be certain, a peach-colour'd sattin does become my complexion hugely. But I think the roses are faded in my cheeks. Well, no matter: he might have gather'd them twenty years ago, had not he been a rover. I hope, however, he has sold his wild oats now, and that I shall yet have the satisfaction to be called my lady Falstaff.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: To be sure, madam; and tho' Sir John is but a knight at present, he will be very assuredly, now the young king is crown'd, be made a great lord, and may be a duke. Indeed, madam, I cannot think of less.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And then shall I be a dutchess, Bridget. Dame Ursula a dutchess!

sp.speaker: Brid,
sp.p: Ay, madam, that will be a day to see; if I am so happy as to be in your grace's favour.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: For certain, Bridget, thou shalt. Well, this love is a strange thing! there is Sir John has deceived me a thousand times, and yet, I know not how, he always persuaded me he was sincere.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: A sure sign you lov'd him, madam.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And yet to be sure, before I receiv'd his letter, I thought I never should hear from him again, and had almost come to a resolution to cast him entirely off.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: In good sooth, madam, that is very prudent; to cast off a lover when we find he will leave us.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: I think so, and not a little imprudent to do it before, for one of my years at least.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Why, madam, you are not so old.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Indeed, but I am—old enough to know I ought not to part with one lover till I am sure of another.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: To be sure, madam, a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush; but the sport of hampering the rogues, who are at liberty, is so vastly pretty.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Ay, if we were sure of catching them at last; but Bridger, Bridget, how often do they escape through our singers and give us the slip! Besides, it is for younger lasses than I to go bird-catching—I cannot throw salt on the tail of a sparrow now.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Nay, lay not so, madam; you forget your new lover, Don Anticho del Pistolo.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Hang him, fustian pated rogue, whoever he be, to pester me with his epistles.—To write letters for his comrade to thee too! well, as I live, I will expose this pair of bombards to Sir John. I will shew him their letters.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Madam, the knight is coming.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Bless us, Bridget, and so he is. Introduce him and leave us.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, my fair princess, see thy wand'ring knight.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Welcome to London, Sir John; thou art indeed a wanderer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A true knight-errant for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Urs,
sp.p: For my sake, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, for thine, my Helen. Have I not encounter'd tremendous giants and fiery dragons, in the rebels of Northumberland and Wales? And then for magicians and enchanted castles: Owen Glandower and his Welch devils we put to the rout; and many a strong hold between here and West-Chester have I visited, releasing fair damsels and distressed 'squires from captivity. I brought two of the latter up to town; I would they were safely immur'd in the country again.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And all these exploits for me, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: As I am a true knight, to lay my laurels at thy feet.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Do you then still love me in sincerity, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Do I love thee? Am I a soldier? Have I courage? Love thee; I will be thy Troilus, and thou shalt be my Cressida.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: You have long told me so, indeed.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And can I lye? Thou shalt be sole possessor of my person and wealth. Thou shalt share in the honours done me at the court of the new king. Thou shalt—but what shalt thou not do? We will be married incontinently.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: O, Sir John, you know your own power, and our sex's weakness: but indeed for decency I cannot so speedily consent. Besides, Sir John, I am not yet put into possession of my estate and monies.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Nay then, as thou sayst, love, for decency's sake,
we must bear with a short delay: but I will no longer be kept out of possession than thou art.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: You shall not, Sir John; and, in the mean time, our lawyers shall confer on the terms of our marriage.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I hate lawyers. Let a priest suffice. Am not I a man of honour?
sp.l: To do thee less than justice were a sin,
Give me thy lips, we'll settle all within.

div2.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div3.head: SCENE I. A Chamber.
div3.stage: Enter Justice SHALLOW and Mrs. QUICKLY, dressed in tawdry cloaths.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: NAY, forsooth, Mr. Shallow, I am too young a widow; much too young to think of a second husband.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not so, fair mistress. If to wed be good, the sooner married still the better sped. My assiduities will make you soon forget your former spouse.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Your acidities, indeed, are very great, Mr. Shallow. But you are too pressing: I cannot so soon forget poor Quickly.—What the goujeres have I said?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Quickly!—I thought your husband name was—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and so it was; but I called him always Quickly, because he was ever so slow. He died, poor man, of a slow melancholy. Always asleep! night and day asleep!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Hah! addicted to somnolency.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ay, so the doctors said. He died of a solemnity, and a solemn end, I warrant ye, he made of it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He was too fat and corpulent perhaps; I am leaner.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he grew fat and burstened, by sotting with his guests, instead of minding the main chance and scoring double.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Say you? Mistress!—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Blisters on my nimble tongue. I say, Mr. Shallow, he was rich, and keeping open house, had store of guests, that made a world of trouble.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Open house, and leave so much behind him: that is rare! he traded greatly?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Greatly, Mr. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: And bore arms.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Two pumpions on a cucumber bed.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: They will quarter.—I'll settle on thee fairly, widow.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Will you, Mr. Shallow?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ecod, I will. Ay, twice as much for such another smile. Odds heart, that look shot through me like an arrow. Nay, I will kiss thee, fackins will I—
sp.stage: [They struggle; Shallow kisses her, and she breaks from him in affected anger.
sp.p: Odds bods! a dainty widow!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You're rude, Sir, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
