sp.p: Hah! gone! then Shallow shall not stay behind, But will pursue and force her to be kind.

div3.head: SCENE II.
div3.stage: Enter Mr. SLENDER and DOL TEARSHEET.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.l: Slender and tender
And no mere pretender.
sp.p: Ha! said I well, Mrs. Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ay, and sung well too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Nay, I have a sweet breath to sing with: that's the truth of it. And yet I warrant you did not know I could sing so well, when you first; fell in love with me.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Oh, fy, Mr. Slender. You make me blush. Young maidens should not be told so, tho' it were true. But, pray, where learnt you now that I was in love with you? Who told you this?

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Marry, that did my uncle Shadow's fencing master, the Don with the hard name. I should otherwise have blushed more by hals than you. Hang me if you had caught me at falling in love first. But one good turn deserves another, as we say in the country.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: To be sure, Mr. Slender hath parts.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p:
Marry, would I might be hanged else. Why, do
you know, that I have had maidens in love with me twice and once before now.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: In the country belike.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Yea, verily, there was Mrs. Anne Page of Windsor, would have given, I warrant ye, more than I wot of, to be married to me.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And you would not have her.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Yes, I would have had her then; but I know not how, they cozened me, and married me to a great lubberly boy.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: To a boy!

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Yes, la! but, for that trick, if ever I marry any body again, I'll take care they don't wear does-skin breeches under their petticoats; that I will.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Nay, it was no such laughing matter that I know of.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.p: Ecod, if you laugh so at me, handsome as you are, I'll go and tell my uncle; so I will.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Go thy way, with God's blessing, for a fool; were it not for thy wealth, Doll Tearsheet would not follow thee.

Don Anticho del Pistolo! what a bombast rogue it is! I knew his hand writing, the moment I saw it. But I have put a spike into the wheel of his contrivance. Dame Ursula and her maid have given these rascals encouragement. If they bite; the scoundrels will be hooked.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Sir John, here is the hobbling friar, that has been so often to ask for you. Shall I say you are at home?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay, let him in.—What can the gouty precisian want with me?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Peace be with you. Sir John, God save ye.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thank thee good father. What is your reverence's will.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I think thou dost not know me, Sir John. It is indeed many years since our personal intimacy: your way of life and mine—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Were something different, father, to be sure: and tho' I may have seen you before, it is so long since I have been at shrift, that I must crave your pardon if I have totally forgot you. And yet your reverence may be ray ghostly father, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Sir John, a man of your age and gravity.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hoh! if your business be to chide me, I shut mine cars.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: If you will not admit your wound to be prob'd; how can you expect to be cured, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Cur'd! 'sblood, I took thee for a priest, and I find thou art a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: A spiritual one, Sir John; and such as your disorder requires.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Dost thou know my case then? A spiritual surgeon sayst thou? I am not given over by the surgeons bodily yet. Who call in the divine till they have sent out the doctor?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I know your case well, Sir John. It is perhaps less your body than your mind that is infected.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, like enough. I have indeed been damnably dispirited ever since the king's coronation. A confounded melancholy hangs upon me like a quotidian ague.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: It is that melancholy, and the cause of it, Sir John, I would remove.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
And how wouldst thou remove it? By providing
me with a charge of horse, and restoring me to the king's favour. I know no other way.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: By inducing thee to repent, and be restor'd to the favour of the King of kings; which thou hast forfeited by a dissolute and abandoned life. Dost thou not think thou art in a state of reprobation?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pray, friar, by what authority dost thou take upon thee to catechise me? Dost thou come out of mere charity, or art thou employ'd by thy superiors?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Suppose the former, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Suppose the former, father friar, why then the devil is so strong in me, that I should be tempted to throw thee headlong down stairs for thy charitable impertinence.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Thy ill-manners, Sir John, would be inexcusable, were it not to be supposed the consequence of an habitual antipathy to every thing that is good. But, I will not lay claim to greater merit than is my due. I am come by order of my Lord-chief-justice; who is so much your friend as to interest himself in your reformation.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My Lord-chief-justice! that's another matter. I cry thee mercy, reverend father. I find thou'rt not the man I took thee for. Your reverence does me honour; and I profess I am much indebted to his lordship's kind love and regard to my soul's health.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: You'll hear me then, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yea, heav'n forbid I should not—what I said was meant against those officious zealots, who are so forward to pry into men's consciences that will not bear the looking into.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Sir John, we know your failings; and shall not put you to the trouble of auricular confession at present.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: There, friar, thou winn'st my heart. Come sit thee down. Wilt drink a glass of sack?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I never do, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I cry thee mercy, then. Here is to your reverence's health; and now, I'll tell thee what,—I do protest, I sit me now upon the stool of repentance, and have been honestly deliberating, some time past, to change my course
of life. I am heartily tir'd of it. Indeed, I am, good father.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I am glad to find thee in such promising dispositions, and think thou couldst not do better than to betake thyself, agreeable to his lordship's intentions, to some monastery, where thou wilt be secluded from temptations, and have all spiritual assistance to encourage thee to mortify the desires of the flesh.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hold thee there, good father. Let me understand thee. What! would his lordship make a monk of me? I must there beg his pardon. A monk; and to mortify the flesh! For heav'ns sake, good father, consider what a mortification indeed that must be to me, who have fix times the quantity of any other man. If I must be included within the pale of the church, why not make a canon of me (not indeed a minor canon) but a prebendary, or a bishop, now. Something might be said for either of these. But for a monk! I know not any thing I am less fit for; unless indeed his lordship had meant to make a running footman of me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Nay, Sir John, his lordship will not use compulsion in this. He will not so far lay a restraint on your inclinations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O, if I ever find myself that way inclin'd; his lordship may depend on it I shall be as ready as ever to follow my inclinations. But the lesson of lean and sallow abstinence is very long and hard, good father; I am not gotten half-way through the first chapter yet.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Some steps, however, Sir John, you must take, toward a more reputable way of life; and that speedily too: otherwise you will be stript of the honours of knighthood; and the king's sentence of banishment will be strictly put into execution against you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
As to the matter of knighthood; once a knight and always a knight, you know. The king may make as many knights as he pleases; but he will not so easily unmake them again. My title will not depend on the king's courtesy, but on that of my followers. I am, notwithstanding, very desirous to give his lordship satisfaction:
and do assure thee, on the honour of a soldier, of the sincerity of my repentance.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: And yet this may be only a transitory fit of penitence, owing to your late disappointment. What reason canst thou give me to hope this state of mind will continue?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, father, what I am shortly going to do is an act, that has confin'd many a man to a state of repentance, which hath continued to the last hour of his life.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: This, Sir John, is saying something. Pray what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I have taken a resolution, father, to—What dost thou think now it is I have resolv'd upon?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Some commendable act of penance, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, it may well be call'd so, I believe. I am determin'd, good father, to marry.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Call you that an act of penance, Sir John? Is marriage a state of mortification?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I wish I may not find it so.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Well, Sir John, marriage is a holy state; and in some degree I approve your resolution; but, in the estimation of the church, it is also an holy act, and ought not to be enter'd into unadvisedly. Your repentance should precede your receiving the benefit of that sacrament.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O, doubt not but I shall repent me sufficiently afterwards.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Ah! Sir John, Sir John, I fear me you are no true penitent: but, however, it may be lawful to salve what cannot be effectually cur'd. I did not expect to make a convert at the first interview. If thou takest any measures that tend toward reformation, thou shalt have my prayers and best assistance therein. Another time I will hold farther conversation with thee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: In the mean time, good father, let me stand fair in your report to my Lord-chief-justice and his majesty.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Thou shalt stand fairer than I fear thou deservest. Farewel.

Fare thee well, good father friar. What an hypocritical puritan! Would not drink sack! Not with the ungodly I suppose. But I am damnably mistaken, if he be not indebted for that rosy countenance and the gout, to the penetrating qualities of old sherris.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well Bardolph, what news dost thou bring?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Marry Sir John, I have just seen a sight that you would have chuckled at.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, mother Quickly and Dol Tearsheet, attired like dames of fashion, and courted by justice Shallow and master Slender. For my own part, I'm out of the plot; but if I find the contrivance is deep: the 'squires are caught. Pistol and Nym are somehow at the bottom of it. That's all I can learn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolph, those knaves would leave me, and set up for themselves. The 'squires are mine; a lawful prey, and shall not be fed upon without our leave. Learn more, and I will bethink me how to counteract the villainous machinations of these runagates. Bur, now, attend me forth.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Now, Bridget, mark me well. That errant knave, Our Spanish suitor, will anon be here. Sir John requests that I do greet him kindly, And give him flattering earnest of success.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Doubt not my cunning: I've been taught ere while to set an egg upon its little end.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: A grannum's secret, Bridget; but no more—What creature's that, who with enormous strides Measures the pavement yonder?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: 'Tis the Don—I will be ready, Madam, when you please, to scare him hence.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Nay, he shall have some sour as well as sweet; Keen as he is, all honey is not meet.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Fair dame, I kiss your hands, your gentle brief, Borne by the winged Mercury, came to hand; And sends your slave to meet his amorous doom.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: I fear, Sir, I have trespass'd on the bounds Of maiden modesty, to write so freely. What will the world say of this strange demeanour?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Breathes he etherial air will dare to east Reflections base on Ursula's fair name?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Indeed, Signior Anticho, I have a woman's timidity, and am apprehensive my behaviour in this particular will seem too light. Affections of so speedy growth are blam'd, as weeds too rank to thrive in true love's garden.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: No general rule's without exception, lady. The object of your choice—Pistolo's fame Will silence all that hear and know his name.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: In that indeed I place my confidence: and yet a stranger, till his worth's approved, however noble in his native soil, is Open to suspicion. Not that your valour, birth, or virtuous fame I mean to question; but to please my phantasy, and justify my conduct to the world, I would know more of your high rank and pedigree. What is the blazonry of its distinction?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Pistolo wears his coat upon his sword. Behold this blade.—The very steel is dy'd [Draws. With blood of Infidels, Jews, Turks, and Moors.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: It hath a scurvy coat upon't indeed.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: True, lady, this no burnish'd Finsbury blade,
Ta'en by young cutlers from their stock in trade,
And in Moorfields on holidays display'd.—
A soldier's weapon this, that bravely fell
In Palestine on Saracens pell-mell
The gift of that renown'd and peerless paragon
Rhodomontado hight, the king of Arragon.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And hath Pistolo's valour then been shown In Palestine? That merit's great, I own.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: There by this sword so many foes were slain, Tnat it was called the flaming sword of Spain.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Indeed! 'Twere much a warrior to withstand, Who comes victorious from the Holy Land.

div3.head: SCENE IX.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Good gracious! madam! Sir John Falstaff.—

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Ha! who? who? what's that? Falstaff didst thou say?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: No matter, Sir, you shall not hence away.
sp.l: It is a quondam sweetheart; whom, for thee,
I shall dismiss with frowns, as thou shalt see.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Heav'ns, madam, I would not for the world Sir John should come in while the cavalier is here. We should have bloody doings I warrant. Did not the knight, when he was as here last, complain of your indifference, and vow vengeance on your new lover?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: By Styx, he'll know and foil me.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Poh! poh! this gentleman fears him not, nor twenty such. Don Pistolo's sword hath been flesh'd among the moors.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Moors! lack-a-day! what talk you of moors? What are simple moors to such a paramour as he. You know, madam, he is in desperation at the loss of your ladyship's affection.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Thou, mistress Abigail, art in the right—Prior pretensions if the knight doth boast, Why happy man be's dole, say I, Il primo venuto il primo servito.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: How's this, signior? Shall not a woman of my age and fashion make my own choice? And can your honour thus desert your fortune?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Desert my fortune! ha! why—what—O, no—

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I claim protection from your sword Against this rude intruder.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Furies!—(Pauses) Oh! I have it.—Enough—thou sayst—my sword thou shalt command 'Gainst pagan recreant or Christian knight Come forth, Toledo,—(Draws) Ha! what's this I see? O blunder vile! unfortunate mistake! My varlet hath equipp'd me with a foil, A blunt and batter'd foil, sans point and temper: It would not parry ev'n a bulwark, this.

div3.stage: [Throws away his sword, which Bridget picks up.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Bridget, let's see—
sp.stage: [Takes the sword, and clapping the point to the ground, bends it double.
sp.l: Alas! 'tis so its plain.
Ha, ha, ha, the flaming sword of Spain!
The gift of that renown'd and peerless paragon
Rhodomontado hight, the king of Arragon!
Nay, do not take my humour thus amiss,
I'm light of heart; but nothing mean t'offend.—
As with this paultry foil thou can'st not fight,
Myself will with't encounter this same knight.
Bridget will safe conduct thee to the gate.
Go, and good tidings speedily await.
The gibbet be my portion, if I trow,
Whether she means to jilt me now, or no:
But fata trahunt—Abigail, lead on,
If Falstaff's near, 'tis time that I were gone.

div3.head: SCENE XI. A Street.
div3.stage: Enter Justice SHALLOW and Master SLENDER.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Take me—take me this letter, I say, to Sir John Falstaff.—That is his suttling-house. I will maul his cloak-bag of chitterlings with my rapier, as I may.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: And will you fight him, cousin? Well, hang me if I carry the challenge. I never could abide the thoughts of cold iron. Even a key put down my back for a bloody nose, ugh—ugh—ugh, would always set me a shuddering.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Don't tell me—if the law will not get me my money, I'll be reveng'd of him. The tun-bellied knave shall not make such a fool of me. I will have his blood or my money.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: His blood! O lud! O lud! Why, cousin Shallow, you are enough to—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Carry me this letter, I say, to Sir John Falstaff. What is it to you? If I am kill'd, you are my heir, and come in for my land and beaves. So, do as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ecod, that's true. I did not think of that: if my cousin's kili'd, I come in for his estate. (Aside) Ay, I'll carry him the challenge. Hey! here he comes, with his bottle-nos'd man, that pick'd my pocket at Windsor.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John! Sir John Falstaff!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir John, justice Shallow calls ye.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What would the blade of spear-mint have with me? I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: But I have not yet done with you, Sir John? I would first have my thousand pound of you again.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You would, master Shallow! like enough! You must take me then in the humour. I am at present illdispos'd to your suit.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut, Sir John. I have said I will not tamely put up this wrong. If I do, I shall be flouted and gib'd to death: I shall be pursued by the mockery of a whole hundred.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not unlikely. But, believe me, the more you bustle in this business, the more you will expose yourself. The more you stir—you know the proverb, master Shallow, it is a little homely, so let that pass. Yet, let me advise thee; rest content.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Content! I am not content. I cannot be content. Nay, I will not be content. Give me back the money, or I will have satisfaction of thee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Satisfaction, sayst thou ? Why, thou wilt not dare me to the combat.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Such provocation would make a coward fight, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: If it make thee fight, I'll be sworn it would: for I have seen thee tremble at the shaking of a wheat ear.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: To be bamboozled! cheated! laught at! I will not put it up. By heav'ns, I will not put it up.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well said, master Shallow. Now I see there's mettle in thee. But surely thou would'st not be the first to break the peace? thou, whose office it is to punish the breach of it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, there are times and reasons for all things. If you will neither give me my money nor gentleman's satisfaction, I will have thee toss'd in a blanket for a poltroon as thou art.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: They must be stout carls, master Shallow, that toss me in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Well, well, we shall see, I'll parley with you no longer. Cousin Slender don't stand shill I, shall I, but give him the note.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, ay, if coz is kill'd, I shall have his estate; and so there's the challenge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
A challenge!—By the Lord, and it is a challenge. I am call'd upon here to meet him on Tower hill incontinently at single rapier. Hoo! what a turluru! In the name of common-sense is the fool turn'd madman? What means the simple tony by this? To get his money again? Does he think by running me thro' the pericardium to become my heir at law? The fearful stag is at bay, and become desperate. But let me see—what's to be done here? I am in person too much of a knight to engage with so little a 'squire.—I have it.—Bardolph, I being your master and a knight, thou art by the laws of chivalry no less than
a'squire. Now, as I take it, this quarrel is properly thine: thou must meet justice Shallow at single rapier.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I, Sir John. He has no quarrel against me. The challenge is given to your honour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: True, but I tell thee my honour disdains to encounter a pitiful 'squire: thou must take my sword and fight him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I shall only disgrace your arms, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to, you will do well. He knows nothing of the sword; and should he challenge thee at pistols, put a charge into each barrel, and present thy nose at him: he will never stand thy fire.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir John, I must be excus'd. I never could fight in my life, unless there was something to be got by it; a booty on the highway, or so.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why 'tis for a thousand pound, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And where's the money?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: At my cashier's.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well then, Sir John, why should we fight for it?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolph, thou art a coward; but no matter. I have a thought: I will meet him myself. Go, fetch the buckler I fought with at Shrcwsbury.

div3.head: SCENE I.
Tower-hill.
div3.stage: Enter PISTOL and justice SHALLOW, stript for the combat.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: DREAD nought, brave 'squire, the knight's a coward rank.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that, and yet I would I had had a lesson or two more, before I had encounter'd him.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Bear thy point thus—sa, sa, friend Shallow, sa.
Do thus, I say, and trust Pistolo's art.
I to the buxom widow will relate
This deed of prowess.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I will essay; but some one comes this way; let us retire, and try that pass again.

div3.head: SCENE II.
div3.stage: Enter Dr. CAIUS and his MAN.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Jack Rugby, follow me Jack Rugby: I ave hear dere is to be duel fought hereabouts, by and by. If de parties be not killed outright, dey may vant assistance. Ve must vatch de opportunity, Jack Rugby.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: To prevent the gentlemen fighting, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: To preventtheir fighting! vat ave we to do wid dat? No, you fool, Jack: to take care of the vounded. Dat is my business.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: But how if the other should run away?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar let him run: he be no patient for me.—Come dis way.

Aha—aha—What a vile mist there is abroad to day! I cannot see a sword's length before me. This must be the spot. But where is the adversary? I would not have him, methinks, lost in the fog. Master Shallow! master Shallow!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir John, here am I.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Saints and good angels guard us! What is this?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come, Sir John, draw, draw.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: It calls me by my name too! Jesu Maria! It is no deccptio visus. In the name of heav'n and earth, what art thou? Ouphe, fairy, ghost, hobgoblin, or demon? Exerciso te.—Pater noster—

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come, Sir John, don't think to put me from my purpose: you know me very well. You know justice Shallow to his cost.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How! can this thing be Robert Shallow, of Gloucestershire, esq justice of the peace, and of the quorum? I took it for some strolling ghost escap'd out of purgatory, by all that's terrible.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, this mockery shall not suffice you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, it is true, as I am a sinner.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Will you fight me, Sir John, or will you not?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Fight thee! When thou seest the princely eagle deseend to encounter the tomtit. What! shall the lofty elephant wield his proboscis against a mite? Shall Sir John Falstaff draw his martial sword against such a pigwidgeon as thou?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: What then did you come here for, Sir John? If you would not be treated as a coward, lay down your target, and draw.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Lay down my target, sayst thou? Who would be fool then? Look ye, master Shallow (since shallow thou wilt be) if I fight, it must be on equal terms. It is but equitable that my body should be secur'd, when I engage with an unsubstantial form; a thing that has none. Dost thou think me such a goose cap as to lay open this fair round belly to the point of thy rapier, when thou presentest not a mark for me. It were as good as pricking at a lottery, ten thousand blanks to a prize, to make a thrust at thee. It were indeed more than a miracle to hit what, rhetorically speaking, is impalpable. But come, if thou must fight with me, thou shalt not say I deal unfairly by thee. To draw my sword would be needless: for hit thee I never shall.—That's siat. Therefore Toledo rest thou in thy scabbard. This is my ward. (Stands on his desence with his target.) Carry thy point as thou wilt: if thou canst not come into me before thou art weary, the money is mine; if thou dost, and woundest: me, I will then—keep it to pay the surgeon. So, come on.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, you are a cowardly knave, and I will kill you if I can.
sp.stage: (They fight. Mr. Shallow thrusts at Sir John, who receives his point always on his target.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well said, master Shallow.—Bravo!—To't again.—Sa—sa.
sp.stage: (Shallow breaks his sword, and Falstaff closes with him, and seizes him by the collar; on which Shal, low falls down on his knees, and Falstaff claps the target on his head.
sp.p: Ha! have I nabb'd you? You should have appointed sticklers, Mr. Shallow. What if I cut thy throat now?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir John, my life is in your hands: but you know you have wrong'd me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well then, thy wrongs be forgotten; and, on that condition, I give thee back thy forfeited life.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: And I hope also you won't bear malice, Sir John against me for the future.

sp.speaker: Fal,
sp.p: By the Lord, not I. I do admire thy magnanimity and valour. Why, thou art the very mirror of prowess, and pink of 'squire errantry. John of Gaunt was a fool to thee. Were I a king, thou shouldst, for this day's work, be made a knight with all the honours of chivalry. Nay, by our lady, I will take majesty upon me, and knight thee myself. Rise up Sir Robert Shallow, knight of the most horrible order of combatants and murderers of the fifth button. And now, Sir Robert, if thou dost not think the tide I've bestow'd on thee worth the thousand pound I owe thee, I will for the first time make restitution. Thou shalt be repaid out of my wife's portion. For thou must know I am this night to be married, and have broke into the round sum to make handsome preparations for my nuptials.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I give thee joy, Sir John; and as I find there is still so much honour in thee, I will open my heart, and confess to thee, that both my nephew Slender and I are going to be married too.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ay! to whom, Master Shallow, to whom?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I to the wealthy widow of Watling-street, and my nephew Slender, to buxom Beatrice her niece, of Bucklersbury.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Master Shallow, you are deceived, Master Shallow. I will be a friend to thee. The widow and her niece are impostors.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Impostors!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Whores! whores, Master Shallow!

sp.speaker: Shal,
sp.p: How, the widow of Watling-street, and Mrs. Beatrice of Bucklersbury—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to, I mean thy widow—Give me thy hand; I will tell thee more as we pass along.

div3.head: SCENE V.
div3.stage: Enter Dr. CAIUS and his MAN.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Dey shake hands!—Eh, morbleu; dey be one brace of cowards. Dat fat knight never once draw his rapier. By gar did we not get more by de malade de France, dan by de English courage, we should not get salt to our pottage, pardie. But, by gar, I will charge them both for my attendance; and if they no pay me, I will expose their no courage.—Come along, Jack Rugby.

div3.head: SCENE VI.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: The train takes fire, and all will soon be flame. The squires are gull'd; and Dol and Quickly take For dames of wealth. The corporal plotted well.

div3.stage: Enter NYM, who gives Pistol a letter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: A letter for Madam Ursula; see if there's humour in it.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Ha! prize or blank! I'll open it, and see Our fortune in the lottery-book of fate.
sp.l: By Jove's bright welkin, 'tis a golden prize.
Nought could withstand the flash of pistol's prime.
She writes us here she scorns the wassel knight,
Who keeps to-day high revels at the globe:
Where if we meet we may in masquerade
Be sped; I to the mistress, you the maid.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Marry-trap, the humour is good; but how shall we know them?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: In purple garb, like nymphs, they'll be array'd; And in feign'd voices speak: the word is soh!
sp.l: Let us about our own disguises strait.
Money buys lands, but weddings go by fate.

div3.head: SCENE VII.
A Ball-Room.
div3.stage: Enter FALSTAFF, with SHALLOW and SLENDER, in domino's. Their masks in their hands.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Marry Sir John, thou hast a pithy pericranium; this is a notable contrivance. I have appointed the parties as you directed to be dressed in purple, and to meet us among the revellers here at the globe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou hast done well, Master Shallow; and I see you and your nephew are cloathed in the same disguises as Nym and Pistol.—You shall see sport, Master Shallow. But see, the maskers come this way. I must go meet the bride.
sp.stage: [Shallow and Slender put on their masks.

div3.stage: [Enter a number of maskers; among the rest Pistol, Nym, Mrs. Quickly, and Doll.
Re-enter FALSTAFF, leading in URSULA, followed by BRIDGET.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Gentles, you're welcome.—You see I come unmasked among you. It were superfluous for him to hide his face who could not be concealed for his belly. Could I mask that indeed, I might pass in disguise. But come, begin the dance: I hope there will be yet concealment enough in this revelry to defeat the rogueries contrived in darkness, and bring them to light.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.p: Nym, who are those in purple vestments clad?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: The two in green.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: In robes of Tyrian dye.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: By their garb they should be the parties; let us accost them. The priest is ready without. We will bespeedy; and, when sped, return unmask'd to tantalize the knight.
sp.stage: [They go up to Quickly and Doll, and take them out.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistol, how now? wherefore hast doff'd thy mask? Art thou the master of this feast? or am I thine?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.l: That is as fortune bids, and time shall shew,
Same mount aloof, while others truckle low.
Sir knight, no more your ancient and base tyke,
Pistol was born to wield the potent pike.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistol, thou art always in the clouds. Art thou drunk? or hast thou got a commission?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Gold honour buys, and Ursula hath store.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How, rascal! dost thou mean to rob my wife?

sp.speaker: Nym,
sp.p: Thy wife! marry that were a good jest.—I see the humour runs well.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Not thine, but mine; proud Basilisco knight! Without, just married, waits thy quondam flame.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To thee?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nym, What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Marry, Sir John, that's the short of it: and I myself was just now married to Mrs. Bridget her woman.

sp.speaker: Falstaff,
sp.p: turning to Ursula. Say, my fair queen of Sheba, is this true? unmask: nay, gentles, all unmask, that we may see what faces are put on.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: You, Sir John, can answer for me.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: And you for me, madam. Marry a corporal indeed! the fellows are drunk.
sp.stage: [Pistol and Nym look at each other with confusion and astonishment; during which time Mrs. Quickly und Dol Tearsheet enter unmasked, and, passing by Pistol and Nym, (who start back with fresh astonishment) go up to justice Shallow and Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How now, you bare-fac'd strumpets! what do you mean? This is no brothel: play no gambols here.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Marry come up, Sir John; you will not hinder my going to my husband. Mr. Shallow will protect me; my dear Mr. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: No, nor me neither, were he twenty Sir John Falstaffs. Sweet Mr: Slender.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Goody Quickly, loose your hold I pray you; I know you, Mrs. Quickly.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ay, and I know you. too, Mrs. Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O ho! do you so? What, Sir John hath blown us; hath he? But no matter; he cannot unmarry us.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, truly, that he can't.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nor would I: for since whores and rogues have conforted, I have never seen four better matched.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I to wise Justice Shallow.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And I to foolish Mr. Slender.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not so, hostess; keep your distance, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: No, no, keep off, Dol, keep off.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Plain Dol! do you hear that Mrs. Slender?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And hostess, truly! do you take that Mrs. Shallow?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Away—ye termagant jades: or I will demolish your frippery.—There are your cuckolds. Pistol, Nym, why stand ye there like mutes? Are you fascinated at the success of your mummery? Or are you ruminating on the comforts of cuckoldom by anticipation.—Take hence your crooked ribs.

div3.stage: [Pistol and Nym go and take Quickly and Dol by the hand.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What, has there been a trick, then, played on us in these disguises? Was I married to you, Pistol?

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.p: Dame Quickly, thou art mine. The fates have cross'd us.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay, I'll be sworn they have joined you.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And was I married to you, Nym?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Even so, Dol. I am heartily sorry for it; but luck hath turn'd tail upon us, that's the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
A very scurvy trick, indeed, but I had so many
husbands before, that one more or less breaks no squares with Dol. Come, Mrs. Quickly, be of good chear: Pistol is better than nobody: he will protect thee, by outswaggering the swaggerers.

sp.speaker: Pistol.
sp.l: Contented I, since so the fates decree,
Soldier no more, a victualler I'll be;
The martial sword exchange for carving knife,
And cut out viands for the means of life.
No more in anger fight, but joyous dine,
And 'stead of drawing blood, draw sparkling wine;
Nay, should Sir John himself my service lack,
At the boar's head, he'll find a glass of sack.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But wilt thou put no lime in it, Pistol?

sp.speaker: Pistol,
sp.p: No, by Falernian Bacchus, for my knight.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Then will I be thy guest. Nay, by'r Lady, thou shalt for once, be mine too. I will not break off the thread of our quondam familiarity with so little grace as Majesty hath done. I do invite ye all, therefore, to supper with me. And if you cannot laugh over the success of your own contrivances, be merry on the consummation of my nuptials.
sp.l: Come, spouse, tho' long indeed hath been our courting,
We're not quite past the days of love and sporting;
'Tis true, a younger bridegroom had you sped,
He might have been less prone to sleep in bed;
Yet, ev'n in autumn, some spring flowers may grow,
As there are lillies in September blow:
Youth's wild oats sown, 'tis ne'er too late to mend;
The worst once past, the better is the end.

lg.l: THE muse of Shakespeare's compliments!—A card
T'excuse this evening's enterprizing Bard!
Great his presumption, to confess the truth:
But, as he pleads the passion of his youth,
Together with the magick of her charms,
Attracting him resistless to her arms;
Tho' somewhat by surprize, she owns, she suffer'd,
Yet, as no actual violence was offer'd,
She's willing, if the audience should agree,
For this one time to set th'offender free.
We women soon forgive, if not forget,
The crimes our beauties make the men commit,
Especially when once we're past our prime,
And Shakespeare's muse, like me,'s the worse for time.
For, tho' she charm with fancy ever young,
Tho' heav'nly musick dwell upon her tongue,
Lost many an artless smile and dimple sleek,
Which sat alluring on her virgin cheek;
Beauties, that faded on the gazer's eye,
And no cold-cream of comment can supply.
As for what Merc'ry in the Prologue told ye;
Pray, let not that from clemency with-hold ye.
That Hermes was of old a lying blade,
And practic'd in imposture, as his trade;
The patron he, or classic lore deceives,
Of cheats, forestallers, higglers, hucksters, thieves.
Besides,—to tell you a stage-trick of ours—
But you'll not spread the secret out of doors,—
The man was no more Mercury, than I am
Queen Hecuba, the wife of Trojan Priam.
A messenger from Phoebus! He a god!
I can assure you all, 'twas Mr. Dodd;
His dropping from the clouds, was all a sham;
And his pretended errand but a flam.
We've heathen gods of paste-board, made to fly
On hempen cords across the painted sky;
Those canvass clouds, that dangle there above,
Inveloping the throne itself of love!
His tale fictitious too, tho' told so glib;
For take it on my word, 'twas all a fib.
Old Falstaff in Elysium!—To my thinking,
So great his natural tendency to sinking,
That to the shades if he had once descended,
To bring him back, not Atlas had pretended.
Dramatic sprites (at least they tell me so)
Dwell not with saints above, nor devils below:
But, form'd th' imagination to engage,
During their short-liv'd passage o'er the stage,
As mere ideal characters exist,
And stand as cyphers mark'd on Nature's list;
To genius giv'n a delegated power
To form these transient beings of an hour,
Which, from this mimic world whene'er they go,
Are free to range in fancy's pimlico,
A limbo large and broad; which in the schools
Is call'd by some the Paradise of Fools.
Feroe naturoe THERE, their preservation
Is purchas'd by no game association:
The poaching plagiary alone denied
A priviege, granted to each bard beside;
Who, tho' a cottager, to try his skill,
May shoot, or course, or hunt them down at will;
In his own paddock may the strays receive,
And scorn to ask a lordly owner's leave.
Not but that bere, the Author of the play,
By me begs leave submissively to say,
"None more than he reveres great Shakespear's name,
"Or glows with zeal to vindicate his same."
